keywords.term: Boma, Democratic Republic of the Congo

div1.p: In accordance with the instructions I left you with, Mr. Nerincx telegraphed you immediately about the Washington nomination for the Consul General of the United States of America in Boma, the moment when the Department of State published it in a statement to the newspapers, which you will find a sample attached in this telegraph.

The designated candidate for this new post Mr. Clarence R. Slocum, of New York, he is actually still the Consul in Weimar. His promotion of Consul General in Boma will not be definitive until after the confirmation by the Senate; but this ratification doesn't seem doubtful to me.

Mr. Slocumm's choice was announced by the Department of State in terms that allow one to think that this nomination is a personal designation of Mr. Root (who recently told me again of his intention to chose a serious candidate) and that she constitutes more a new éspec. for our Boston adversaries.

The statement reports in fact that despite the reproach of the Congo Reform Association, the Secretary of State did not decide on the creation of this Boma post after being assured the good will of the Independant State,— he then decided to name a candidate to this post clear of influences of this antagonistic association, — and again today, despite the steps and the authority in which the Congo Reform Association preoccupies, the Secretary of State declared to these reformers that he is sticking to his manner of seeing things about this Congolese issue as he had made known earlier.
The same report adds that the welcome given to the proposed candidates by the Secretary of the Congo Reform Association, Mr. Daniels, has not been in the least encouraging.
Please, Sir Knight, accept the insurance of my very highest consideration.
